metadata.h1: The Most Popular Tools and Software for Data Science

all_paragraphs: Apache Hadoop is one of the most prominent tools in managing big data.

It also allows the users to store all forms of data, that is, both structured data and unstructured data. With Hadoop, data scientists can have reliable distributed processing of large volumes of data in a dataset across clusters of computers.

Hadoop isn’t pressingly required to become a Data Scientist, but a data scientist must know how to get the data out in the first place to do analysis, and Hadoop is exactly the technology that stores large volumes of data, where a data scientist can work on.
Hadoop consists of several modules: Hadoop Common, Hadoop Distributed File System, Hadoop YARN, Hadoop MapReduce for flexible data processing.

MongoDB is a tool to explore data structured as you see fit. As a NoSQL database, it doesn’t follow the strict relational format imposed by SQL. By providing capabilities that typically require adding layers to SQL, it collapses complexity. With the dynamic schema, you can handle vastly different data together and consolidate analytics.
Alternatively, there are alternative NoSQL tools — Cassandra, CouchDB, ArangoDB, Postgre SQL, or DynamoDB that be used to transfer the data to a platform that provides reliable data management.
SQL is one of the most requested skills in Data Science.

To get data from a database, you need SQL. Amongst SQL platforms — MySQL, Microsoft SQL Server, Oracle Database, PostgreSQL, MongoDB, CouchBase, DB2, or other databases, Oracle’s database solution emerges as the winner in the majority of surveys conducted in 2019.

MySQL and Microsoft SQL Server rounded out in the top three. Although the database management industry contains some of the largest companies in the tech industry such as Microsoft, Oracle, and IBM, several free and open-source DBMSs such as PostgreSQL and Apache Cassandra remain highly competitive.

While everyone is so busy learning R or Python for Data Science, we tend to forget that there is no Data Science without data. SQL is needed for Data Scientists to get that very data and to work with it. SQL allows storage, querying, to create, parse, and manipulate data fast and easy — basically data management.

An open-source and world’s leading graph database management system developed by Neo Technology Inc., Neo4j is a type of database that uses graph structures for semantic queries with nodes, edges, and properties to represent and store data.
It is designed for optimizing fast management, storage, and traversal of nodes and relationships, which is highly scalable, built to leverage data and their relation.
Neo4j provides scalability, high-availability, and flexibility for CRUD operations on data. The tool is written in Java. and provides a flexible data model to give real-time output.

SAP HANA (High-Performance Analytic Appliance) is an RDBMS, developed and marketed by SAP. Its primary function as a database server is to store and retrieve data as requested by supporting applications.

SAP HANA, an ETL based replication uses SAP Data Services to migrate data from SAP or non-SAP source to target the HANA database. Businesses using SAP in their biosphere use HANA to process massive amounts of real-time data in a short time.
Because SAP is a closed-source ecosystem, HANA might not be a tool for independent Data Scientists but for business or careers in SAP, HANA can be a good skill to flaunt.

Apache Hive is a data warehouse software project built on top of Apache Hadoop for providing data query and analysis. Hive resembles a SQL interface for querying data stored across databases and file systems to later integrate with Hadoop.
Hadoop, Hive, Pig essentially work hand-in-hand at data management levels.

Hive is known for providing data summaries, data querying majorly. HIVE was built with a vision for people working and in the knowledge of SQL need not require to learn an entirely new language to fetch and interact with data in the Hadoop ecosystem.
Apache Spark is a unified analytics engine for large-scale data processing. It can write applications across a variety of languages which makes it robust — Java, Scala, Python, R, and SQL.

Data Scientists use Spark for data cleansing and transformation, feature engineering, model building, model evaluation scoring, and “productionalizing” data science pipelines. I read Spark strives to provide an experience similar to that of Pandas from Python which interests me.
I do not know much about Apache Spark but I will be learning it in Fall 🙈. If you are interested in learning more about Apache Spark, here is a good resource for reference.

RapidMiner is an open-source, fully transparent, powerful end-to-end data mining tool for rapidly building predictive models. The tool supports hundreds of data preparation and machine learning algorithms to support a range of data mining projects.

RapidMiner can be used for preparing data, machine learning, and model development. It supports multiple data management techniques and machine learning steps like data preparation, data visualization, predictive analysis, deployment, and so forth. The tool is written in Java.

Microsoft Power BI is an interactive data visualization and analytics tool for Business Intelligence. I heard of Power BI in 2017 when I was interning with Larsen & Toubro, using Power BI for revenue expense analysis across departments, employee efficiency, real-time data processing for welding and arching shifts.
Data Scientists can pull data from a wide range of sources and create beautiful dashboards to track metrics important to a business

The Microsoft blog on Why Power BI explains very clearly and justifies why PowerBI is a de facto to Data Scientists. Power BI easily connects to, models, and visualizes data, creating memorable reports personalized with KPIs for a brand.
Power BI can easily integrate with Microsoft Office applications — Microsoft Teams and Excel, that empowers data-driven business decisions at an organization to drive them into strategic actions.

Tableau is a very popular and powerful data visualization tool used in Business Intelligence these days. Data analytics is rapid and robust with Tableau. With the visualization dashboards and worksheets, Tableau covers simplifying raw data into a very easily understandable format, cleaning data, and identifying underlying trends and patterns.

For quite some time now, big firms like PepsiCo, Verizon, Charles Schwab, Coca-Cola, Chipotle are using Tableau to leverage their data and make conclusive informed decisions. A tool like Tableau is a must-know for anyone interested in a Data Science or Data Analytics career.
Think of pie charts, line charts, pivot tables, bar charts, and more 📊, QlikView is a tool that is widely used across domains in the industry.

QlikView again is a Business Intelligence cum data discovery tool when the goal is to create guided analytics applications and dashboards for targeted business challenges. The software enables users to uncover data insights and relationships across various variables.

There has been quite a debate on Tableau vs QlikView. While Tableau has bog brands in the pocket, QlikView uses an in-memory data model making it capable of manipulating huge data sets instantly with accuracy which is Tableau’s scope of improvement.

Spotfire was a business intelligence company based in Somerville, Massachusetts that was bought by TIBCO in 2007 (Wikipedia). Spotfire comes with the same general visualization capabilities as Tableau or QlikView.

While Tableau Public and Power BI Desktop is free to use, TIBCO Spotfire pricing starts at $650.00 per year, per user. There is no free version which might make it a less popular amongst independent Data Scientists. However, I recently came across this story on how Accor Hotels used TIBCO Spotfire to improve customer experience, and faster, easier, simpler integration.
TIBCO, an originally global leader in integration and analytics had a huge clientele with Spotfire in the kitty. You can visit the TIBCO customer list here.
Did you think this would not be on the list? Python crushes it all when it comes to numbers.

The object-oriented nature of Python facilitates data scientists to execute tasks with better stability, modularity, and code readability. While Data Science is only a small portion of the diverse Python ecosystem, Python is rich with specialized deep learning and other machine learning libraries and popular tools like scikit-learn, Keras, and TensorFlow.

Undoubtedly, Python enables data scientists to develop sophisticated data models that can be plugged directly into a production system. Python has a plethora of packages and libraries not just for data analytics but everything leading to that.

The data analysis library for Python, Pandas is hands down the best you can get for data exploration. Organized into data frames, Pandas can filter, sort, and display data with all the ease you can imagine.

The quintessential statistical tool for Data Science, R is not just a language but an entire ecosystem in itself to perform statistical calculations. It facilitates to perform operations on data processing, mathematical modeling, data visualization with built-in functions.

R was built to do the statistical and numerical analysis of large data sets and therefore, there are a plethora of operations that can be performed for Data Analysis and Exploration — sort data, transpose tables, create plots, generate frequency tables, sampling data, probability distribution, merge data, variable conversions and much more. Explore packages dplyr and tidyr for the best results.

Alike R, SAS is a tool developed for advanced data analysis and complex statistical operations. It is a closed-source proprietary tool that offers a wide variety of statistical capabilities to perform complex modeling. SAS is mostly used by large scale organizations and professionals due to its high reliability.

While SAS is not a tool best suited for beginners and independent data science enthusiasts it SAS is tailor-made to meet advances business demands, if you are looking to specific Data Science roles in your career, a good knowledge of SAS would gleam your profile.

SAS has been an undisputed market leader in the enterprise analytics space, however, to compare its capabilities with Python or R, SAS may seem difficult to model and visualize data with. Plus, the learning curve is tricky, difficult sometimes, and is mostly used by large corporations with huge budgets.

MATLAB is the first tool I used for Data Science. I had MATLAB as an image processing tools in one of my undergrad classes when I discovered MATLAB as an effective tool for profound mathematical operations. While Data Science was also a lot about math, I took a chance to explore what made this technology a powerful tool for mathematical modeling, image processing, and data analysis.

MATLAB holds a vast library of mathematical functions for linear algebra, statistics, Fourier analysis, filtering, optimization, numerical integration, and solving ordinary differential equations. MATLAB provides built-in graphics for visualizing data and tools for creating custom plots.

I don’t know a lot of Data scientists using MATLAB. Having said that, it is undeniable that it is great for math and modeling. With the advent of R and Python in the Data Science domain, MATLAB has been on a fall but still there as we also see above in the stats.

The IBM SPSS software platform offers advanced statistical analysis, a vast library of machine learning algorithms, text analysis, open-source extensibility, integration with big data, and seamless deployment into applications.

IBM SPSS is a relatively lesser used tool, I can say. It is more popular among research scholars and academicians for research studies in the area of social sciences, psychology, finance, human resource, etc. While most data scientists and industries use R, Python, or SAS as primary tools, SPSS is a great tool if you’re working in the area of psychology or related field.

Stata is a powerful statistical software that enables users to analyze, manage, and produce graphical visualizations of data. It is primarily used by researchers in the fields of economics, biomedicine, and political science to examine data patterns.

As the official website of Stata says “Data scientists rely on Stata because of its strong programming capabilities, reproducibility, extensibility, and interoperability. From data wrangling to reporting, Stata provides the tools you need to accomplish your analysis. Permissive licensing allows you to easily integrate it into your proprietary workflow.”
RiverLogic is a modeling and analytics platform that leverages diagnostic, predictive, and prescriptive analytics to conduct what-if and optimization analysis.
Its prescriptive analytics platform enables users to solve an unlimited number of decision-making challenges through collaborative, rapid, cloud-based scenario analysis.
SAP Lumira lets Data Scientists and Analysts build impactful business intelligence visualizations to assess risk, improve efficiencies, highlight unique insights, and identify opportunities.
SAP Lumira also supports OLAP technology for advanced analysis. The visualizations with Lumira offer adaptive layout containers for interactive and effective data analytics.

Thank you for reading! I hope you enjoyed the article. Do let me know what tools did you know or not know before and are looking forward to learning or exploring in your Data Science journey?

Rashi is a graduate student at the University of Illinois, Chicago. She loves to visualize data and create insightful stories. When not rushing to meet school deadlines, she adores writing about technology, UX, and more with a good cup of hot chocolate.
